commentBody: FYI the link to this article from the app is broken.

Other than the broken link (again?!), this was a perfect Frday puzzle for me: Tough, but not as hard as a typical Saturday; fair; and fun. What more could one ask?   

I may be the only one who read the title "A Christmas Story" in that clue and thought it was "A Christmas Carol". Yes, the depredations of age. I knew OVALTINE was an old-time product (one I even enjoyed as a child) but ‚Äî To think! ‚Äî it was around during Dickens's time. Who knew!

Just the kind of challenge I love in a Friday puzzle!  

ENNEAD is one of my favorite words, so I get an extra bit of delight when it shows up in a puzzle.

Smooth puzzle with some interesting entries and little junk.  I tried naughahyde (yes misspelled I know) before ULTRASUEDE (which I‚Äôd never heard of), but was quickly disabused of that notion.

I smiled at the clue about A Christmas Story, a holiday favorite for us.  The Jean Shepherd story on which it is based is great too.  Jean Shepherd is an American unicorn, a good writer and a great raconteur. Listening to him on WOR radio back in the early seventies was a big part of my late childhood.  As for OVALTINE, well the less said the better.
Well-constructed with lots of interesting answers, but fell into place for me much faster than a typical Friday.
Either easier than usual or I was on the exact same wavelength as the constructor. Either way, enjoyable puzzle!
Don't forget to drink your OVALTINE!
For 31D, my guess is that moss is covering for a forest floor. Enjoyed the puzzle!

I can‚Äôt tell whether it was a crunchy Friday or that it‚Äôs 4am and my brain‚Äôs not putting the pedal to the metal, but it took me longer than normal. I really liked the fill. Good puzzle. 

ELOTE was new to me, even though I speak pretty good Spanish. The secret to my ‚Äúpretty good Spanish,‚Äù however, is Latin and, wouldn‚Äôt you know it, those uncooperative Spaniards had gone and got themselves their word for ‚Äòcorn‚Äô in the New World, from Nahuatl. Live and learn. 

Also, while I knew that silkworms were domesticated, I didn‚Äôt know that SILK  MOTHs were as well‚Äîor that there was such an insect in the first place‚Äîso another TIL for me. 

And lastly, as I‚Äôm sure this will come up in the comments today, I say OLDIE BUT GOODIE, with an ‚Äôan‚Äô before ‚Äòoldie‚Äô if in a sentence, but no ‚Äòa‚Äô before ‚Äògoodie.‚Äô  It‚Äôll be interesting to see how different folks‚Äô mileage will vary on this. 

Signing off for another couple hours of sleep. Thanks for a great puzzle, Kelly. Happy Friday, everyone.
17a might be clued as ‚ÄúBygone symbol of national dignity‚Äù or ‚ÄúFormer symbol of bygone national dignity‚Äù.

Thumbs up to this puzzle overall, especially for all the fresh interesting long entries. I loved the central crossers, love the phrase LIKEABOSS, love the clue for SOLOCAREER, and love the trivia fact cluing SILKMOTH. Admittedly there was some inconsistent areas in terms of difficulty and some fill that may irritate some people‚Äîis TNIA Miller going to be the next celebrity we have to memorize for their crossword friendly name along with ESAI and NIA and AYO and ISSA? Calling the Brady family an ENNEAD seems like calling the three STOOGES a triumvirate (and what about Tiger and Cousin Oliver?) Between that, the unknown FLOG to me and going back and forth between GERM and SEED I definitely had some pause in the north and middle east. Still it was more than made up for by OLDIESBUTGOODIES like GARBO and OVALTINE and great clues for GURNEY, MOSS and GYM. So kudos from me.
Not sure how "wire holders" works out to be "pylons" (25D).  I must be missing some context.  But got it easily from the crossings.

A smooth solve except for T'NIA. I enjoyed her in The Diplomat but I didn't know her name and so that section was a bit of a Natick for me.

Not crazy about the Othello quote; a bit spicy for the crossword, no?  One of the most vulgar lines in Shakespeare IMO. So many other ways to clue IAGO.

But other than that enjoyable and crunchy.

My eyesight is rather poor, so I don't generally count squares when considering answers.

Thus I got myself all hopeful that 19A would be "Clippy."

All my friends tell me this leather is amazing, but I can't be suede.

(Maybe I need some new material.)
Fast and fun

oughtnt to be solving no friday in no 20 minutes nohow.
maybe i am getting better...

I knew the nomad dwelling had to be either a tenT or a yurT, but TNIA being somebody's name just wouldn't compute for me. I finally broke down and looked it up.

I also had to check the meaning of that word I'm not even going to try to spell here.

This was generally a very hard puzzle for me, which required Saturday time. 

Apparently my not being a native English speaker or resident of an English-spewking country mattered today. It doesn't, always, but on some days it is a major hurdle. For example, I figured out HEATING PAD in the end, but it was quite a struggle. We have the thing over here, of course, and I occasionally use one myself, but we call it "poduszka elektryczna", "electric pillow".

I have no idea why GYMS are elliptical areas, and the column is little help, because I don't know what elliptical exercise equipment is. I'm not a gym goer, and all the related terminology I know is Polish.

ULTRASUEDE is a brand name, I guess? That NW corner was horrific for me, but I did figure it out without Google. One of the few things I knew there was TRENT. A major Italian highway skirts that city, and over the decades I drove by it multiple times. Finally, two years ago my wife and I decided to finally spend a day there. It was well worth it - then old town, the Renaissance castle, romanesque cathedral and underground ancient Roman street museum were very interesting. 

Strangely, I remembered the Bessemer process from my highschool studies of the industrial revolution.
30 minutes exactly. I had to go back over it to find a mistake and I'm glad of it now (because of the time).

Elliptical areas was a great clue.  The rest of the puzzle was... fine.  Sort of Saturday-ish I guess, maybe.

I don't know why pylons are "wire holders" and am a little tired of names that have spilled from a Perquackey tumbler, but I know I have to deal and that all names are made up anyway.

Whatever, looking forward to a fun themed puzzle.  Saturdays have become tiresome.

Thank you, Kelly, for a fun puzzle!

I was delighted to be reminded of a third grade science project:  We took home silkworms, tended them, fed them mulberry leaves, and I heaved a sigh of relief when a cocoon appeared.  We were told there would be a moth inside, but I don't remember seeing it emerge. 

Another, less successful project, was a sweet white rat I volunteered to keep at home when school closed for summer vacation. My mother made a cardboard box for it, but it didn't work because the rat tipped over the water dish to soften it up for an escape hole. We managed to catch her and put her back in different box, but not before she had managed a romantic liaison with an unknown basement rat. We thought the resulting five brown offspring were very cute, until their mom rigged a break one night and the box was totally empty the next morning.  My mother pointed out that we now had a houseful of rats.

(Best not to go into what ultimately happened, a horrifying drama, with one truly awful scene involving our fox terrier, "Cracker.")
Too much trivia for my taste. We're still doing obscure actors from a hundred years ago?

Thought it was oldie but goldie? And I agree, let's keep the 'creative' names out of the actor clues. On the whole too much random trivia, not enough actual clever clues. It seems to be a 'shortcut' too many puzzle creators are taking lately to create difficult crosswords.
Grrr. üò° I‚Äôve tried to post twice tonight and nothing‚Ä¶

Really nice Friday. Reading the constructor notes. I‚Äôm guessing she is pretty young.  But success came early and often. Congrats. 

TNIA was tough. 
Growing up watching Brady bunch.  I was frustrated I couldn‚Äôt figure out the answer. What‚Äôs an ENNEAD versus a nonet?  Anyway. Thanks for reminding of the show. And the tic-tac-toe grid with all nine of the characters.
The long answers aside, this is the epitome of an unfun crossword for me. A quiz about obscure names and a vocabulary lesson.
Sorry but that crossword was abysmal. Either improve the hints or choose less obscure synonyms!

Wanton doesn‚Äôt pair well with idle. Ennead has religious/cultural implications that don‚Äôt jive with the clue. And if I have to look up an actor‚Äôs name it‚Äôd be nice if it was at least someone more significant. Could‚Äôve been more fun with different clues.
Sorry, not for me.  I don't like to look things up and this seemed rife with random trivia. Movie(s) from 1928?  I got the double crossing and finally gave up.
This is as far as I got. Several guesses in there that may not be correct. https://imgur.com/a/R4InSHU

ENNEAD?? Argh! I had to do an alphabet run for the A, crossing with TNIA. 

Not complaining, though, it was a fun puzzle. I too read Dickens into 35A, but I picked up on that brain slip after a few crosses. Now OVALTINE and a Christmas Story I know very well! A lot better than Dickens, even that sappy holiday standby with Mr Scrooge. 

TIL a few things, like the OVA and SILKMOTH clues. 

Greta GARBO is not even close to obscure. I'd put her in the "eternally famous" category, and the Mysterious Lady film fits easily with "I vant to be alone", Garbo's famous wish.
Thanks so much for ULTRASUEDE!

Just solved the Atlantic xword and TNIA made an appearance., clued as "VisionQuest" actor.  I was thrilled to be able to pop it right in!  

So yes, T'NIA is a name to remember.

Blimey, that felt tough but actually solved pretty quickly.  I see there‚Äôs not a lot of love for it in the comments but I thought it was a fair Friday with a couple of Naticks.

TIL that you don‚Äôt call them PYLONS across the pond.

Yes the odd name (no offence intended) and ENNEAD were show stoppers, especially as I have no clue who (what?) the Brady‚Äôs are, but the crosses filled in for me. I don‚Äôt know the Christmas Story, so where does OVALTINE come in? We used to dish it out as the bedtime drink for patients when I was a nurse, with its own stirrer/smusher thing to get the lumps out. Never drank it myself as the smell and appearance turned my stomach, but it was popular among the OLDIES.  Thanks for the memory ü§¢

This went better than mu usual Friday. Just kept slogging away. Did need help with the names. Almost always do. I love the long answers. A really fun puzzle. Thanks, Kelly! Y‚Äôall have a wonderful weekend! We‚Äôre gonna be cold in our NC mountains starting Monday! ü•∂ I cannot wait! It‚Äôs why we moved here!

Smooth Friday made easier by the crossing spanners that pretty much filled themselves in.  I did waste time by first writing in OLDIE BUT GOOD___ and realizing it was too short, but my eraser took care of that.  

The fill was nice, especially SILK MOTH, ENNEAD and  LIKE A BOSS.  

I liked seeing HEATING PAD instead of drugs for a change.
Anyone saying Oldie but goodie instead of Oldie but goldie has, frankly, stopped trying.

My covid wracked brain was never up to this one.

But even in a healthier state, I don't think I would ever get ATSEA from [Bamboozled].  Geez.  Bamboozled to me indicates deception, not confusion.  Just my opinion but I think that's a hugely bizarre clue.

I've heard of flogging a dead horse, but "promoting shamelessly"?  I find fault with that.

The NW was torture.  ULTRASUEDE?  I got the "suede" part,  but ULTRA?

I got STENO, but couldn't rely on it because there was no indication of it being a shortening of the real term, stenographer.  I know that late week puzzles don't adhere to the rule of indicating shortenings, but still it was quite beyond me tonight.

The "aha" moments were entirely absent.  Oh, it's a ROSEGARDEN, and not a beerGarden or winEGARDEN. 

ELOTE is a total unknown to me. You don't get "ahas" from complete mysteries.  

Then again, I feel so crappy that the only puzzle that would have made me happier would been one that actually climbed off the page and murdered me, getting me out of this state of delirium.

I'm reduced to being desperate in wanting to taste something again.

I don't even want to think about Saturday.

I'm reminded of a Mad magazine cartoon sequence.  A very depressed man walks by a sidewalk salesman selling ties.  The sign says "Brighten up your day--buy a tie!"

The last frame the guy had hung himself with the tie he bought, and he had a huge smile on his face.

All of life appeared somewhere in Mad Magazine.

I had YURTS fairly early, but had to take it out when I put in OVALTINE (which was a gimme for me).  Surely no one has a name that begins "TN".
Meet T'NIA Miller.
Oh, but we've already met.  Looking her up on the Interwebs, I recognized her immediately.  She's been in "The Diplomat" and "Sex Education", both of which I've watched.
Now I know (and will remember?) the name.

ENNEAD crossed with TNIA is a natick. Sorry, it just is.
Nice puzzle, otherwise.
That was a great Friday puzzle
15 minutes..fast for me..I couldn't believe Tnia could be correct....but I had confidence in my crossing answers.
Quick solve but all the random unknown trivia made this solve unenjoyable. It serves absolutely no purpose.

Today's ear worm:

Here's the story of a lovely lady,
Who was bringing up three very lovely girls.
All of them had hair of gold, like their mother,
The youngest one in curls.

Here's the story of a man named Brady,
Who was busy with three boys of his own,
They were four men, living all together,
Yet they were all alone.

It's nearly impossible to think of this song without seeing in one's mind's eye the little three-by-three prison of that "mixed family" (and Alice!) each in their own little cell, eyeing one another, forming that famous ENNEAD.

Two of my single-digit-aged staples: Straight Ovaltine by the spoonfuls, and St. Joseph's orange aspirin by the fistfuls. How my palate has evolved...never thought of combining them then but if I knew then what I know now I might have had a much more serious habit!
My initial ‚ÄúCan‚Äôt be!‚Äù reaction to TNIA made that name backward feel appropriate.

Oh, that lovely feeling when I return to a sticky area in the grid for the third or fourth time and with a boom an answer hits me.  That happened several times today to my delight. And ‚Äì ain‚Äôt the brain amazing in how it works under the radar?

Also lovely is when a solve is enhanced by beauty: IDLE RUMOR, SILK MOTH, FLOG (as clued), GRUB, SEEMLY, GARBO, LUCRE, LET IT RIDE.

Those first two are NYT answer debuts, and this puzzle had an ennead of them, with neverr-seen-before clues hitching on to those new answers, bringing spark.

A pastiche for me of easy and hard, hitting that sweet spot between trudge and mindless. 

I got magnificently misdirected by [Shipping container], and smiled at the PuzzPair¬© of PINS near a backward GOLF.  

Thus, I was wonderfully walloped by a dollop of good today.  Thank you so much for this, Kelly!

Very hard for me--missed my Friday average by four minutes.

I was hoping for Naugahyde (remember when you could buy a stuffed Nauga?). Never heard of Fannie HURST, but fair enough. There's really a person called TNIA, though? Really?

STENO was my first fill, got the larval worm before the MOTH, and just kept pushing until I was there.

Oh, and in the immortal words of Kenny Bania: Why do they all it Ovaltine? The jar's round, the mug's round. They should call it Roundtine.

Thanks!

Like today's constructor, I was amazed to learn that one could find vulgarities like "the beast with two backs" and "country matters" in the line of the "immortal Bard", and the discovery was one of the early lessons that taught me that learning could be fun.

Whenever I hear the line "the beast with two backs", I think of a production of Othello I saw many years ago, in which the actor playing IAGO created a hand gesture to illustrate the "beast", making the line even more vulgar.  He intertwined the fingers of his two hands and made his palms go back and forth.
Amazing how such a scene can stay with one for so long!  The power of great art, and the recognition that Art can also be "vulgar"!

Far from brutal, but required a tinge of the Bessemer Process.

And oldie but a goodie got me started up: I ‚ÄúOh, Mr. Grant!‚Äù

I liked the polar puzzle pair of
FLIP OUT ON 
next to
LET IT RIDE.


OVALTINE 
over
OLDIE BUT A GOODIE
seemed apt.


And POSER next to LUCRE reminded me of somebody. We probably all know a phony rich person.

I almost needed a HEATING PAD after TRANSVERSing this chewy grid. Thanks, Kelly!

I know it's been said already, since I always read all the comments, but have to put in my two cents' worth. It's not OLDIE BUT A GOODIE, but An oldie but goodie. For your enjoyment: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5aH7NsW5QfI https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Those_Oldies_but_Goodies_(Remind_Me_of_You)
Pretty smooth but TNIA sure caused some agita.  Nice one.
The upper right fell last (had to look up 13-down).   I have never heard the word FLOG used in that context.
If I keep on beating my average like this then pretty soon I‚Äôll have the puzzle done before it‚Äôs published
40 across: talk about "Greek to me"! Sheesh
Without the key,  this puzzle would have been extra hard for me.
I loved T'Nia Miller in The Fall of the House of Usher and The Haunting of Bly Manor, but I didn't know her name until I looked it up.
Woulda been cute if the answer for 29D had been five letters long (T'NIA) and the crossing word something like WOULDN'T.

oof, bottom left with "joissance", "victuals", and "long way to go", I just got stopped in my tracks

Also, I call for a moratorium on using modern micro-celebs who have unique names. You can seemingly take any 4-letter combo and find some random person who was in a Broadway show named utqa or whatever. Feels like the puzzle maker is starting with the letter combo and then backing into the name as a crutch.

For a puzzle with such a mix of OLDIEs and more recent expressions, not to mention the long-since writer and the (apparently newer) actress with an incomprehensible name, this one solved rather quickly.  I have no explanation for that...good crosses?  Just enough Shakespeare? An especially good history text (Brinton, Christopher, and Wolf?) plus some random reading such as _The Secret History_ (basically a hatchet job on Justinian's wife Theodora)...

I had EATS before GRUB and GERM before SEED.
Otherwise, smooth sailing.
I'll see y'all tomorrow; meanwhile, "Be sure to drink your OVALTINE!"

This was moderately challenging, though I finished about three minutes under my average, with the help of looking up T‚ÄôNIA Miller. I wish I‚Äôd trusted my crossing fills, but doubted the T-N‚Ä¶ah, well. OVALTINE‚Ä¶yes, I can see, vividly, Ralphie decoding the super secret message, only to discover, to his disgust, it means ‚ÄúDrink more OVALTINE.‚Äù However, whenever I think of the beverage, the first voice that comes to me is Cloris Leachman, in Young Frankenstein. https://youtu.be/lcgEN3CaqXs?si=RNlQTdg-IujId3rX
"Jouissance" just made my day! Great word.

Typical tough Friday for me, and had to look up a couple of things, but then just a lot of pondering and working the crosses. Ended up being an enjoyable workout. 

Nine debut answers in this one, and for at least a couple of those it was surprising that they'd never appeared before.

Thanks, Kelly, for constructing such a fabulous puzzle! I found it to be a perfect Friday full of challenging clues (Brady family was a great one as I tried to fit in "blended," "modern" (for the era), etc. Alice did make it a perfect ENNEAD for one of my favorite childhood shows! Well done and hope we'll keep seeing more from you!

Happy Friday, everyone!
Still not working! Please fix the app :( haven‚Äôt been able to play since Tuesday

Solving a Friday puzzle in Wednesday time - a new personal best for me

just got a lot of the longs ones right of the bat

full puzzle enjoyed it after that twister of a Thursday
Fresh, smart and satisfying!
Watching ‚ÄúLive with Kelly and Mark‚Äù  while reading Wordplay, and guess who‚Äôs going to be on next Monday - Ali Larter!
Wow, very challenging!
Word of the day: ennead
Wow. No way I thought TNIA was gonna fly.

And my puzzle find today. A Monday from August 6, 2001 by Bernice Gordon. Just three theme answers in that one - all of them appropriate fairly frequently for most of us: EXCUSEMEPLEASE IMTERRIBLYSORRY IBEGYOURPARDON Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=8/6/2001&g=50&d=A ...

As a child I read classic comics. When we were tested for AP lit. I knew the plot lines and key events for all (e.g.: I knew the name of Prince Valiants son) and was readily accepted into the class. I have this paper to thank for my A in civics and a good score on the Foreign Services Officers Test (FSOT).

Thank you Kelly

TNIA crossing ENNEAD left me with some deep uncertainty about spellings when I didn't get the music, which I spent some time on before giving up to see if indeed TNII was someone's name. Poor YURTS being entered and erased so many times.

Thought this was a good Friday puzzle, the kind where the first pass makes me think ‚Äòthis is impossible‚Äô but by chipping away at it it all comes together. Add me to the list of people who wrote and erased YURTS many times.

Today I had the crossword in one hand, and Google open with the other! 

Despite the dogpile I received yesterday for my criticisms, readers will be happy to know I enjoyed this a lot! I found some answers questionable, but when won‚Äôt I? üòâ Overall this was a strong construction, and an enjoyable experience to solve. Perhaps a little too much reliance on actor‚Äôs names, but I throughly enjoyed the, count ‚Äòem, TWO(!) Shakespeare answers!! So, I‚Äôll take what I can get and leave the actors for Google. üòä

Have a great Friday all!
I had no idea that Shakespeare was the source of that euphemism. Next, you'll be telling me that Laertes was doing the horizontal mambo with Hamlet's mom.

On the first pass through this gem, I was skeptical on hitting my average - but once I hit the right "cluing to answer" wavelength, surprised myself with a 15:55, no lookups, straight to the song finish. 

28A and 29D were my last fills and I truly want TNIA to show up more often! This was beautifully constructed and clued. Fave.

Imagine my jouissance!! A day is not wasted when you can combine Brady Bunch knowledge with vocab.
Kelly constructed this puzzle LIKEABOSS.
Have a happy Friday!
I hate this new Comments format. All the replies are out of context! I know you can follow the ‚ÄúThread‚Äù link, but the way it was before was far easier to follow. Please fix this!

Another thought provoking thread erased by the emus, about whether questioning the inclusion of TNIA was racist or not. I wasn‚Äôt offended by the original post and I hope no one was offended by my response. Heavens, if we can‚Äôt even have civil conversations about racism how can we begin to confront it?

Back to trivia heaviness.

If I look up the word and the first line in the definition gives away the answer, seems not like a clever clue. Just a vocab test. Feels more like homework than puzzle solving.

Wish the puzzles relied more on solving and less on lookups.
OK, ENNEAD was a definite guess, and totally obscure. But that's what puzzles are sometimes, right?

A real baffler. Almost an hour of guesses rejected by Autocheck finally paid off, but with lots of "Huh? What's that?" for the wild guesses that got accepted.
This one was lots of fun. Challenging enough to run on a Friday but much more on my wavelength than yesterday‚Äôs puzzle, which I really struggled with. Thanks Kelly Morenus! üëèüèªü§ì

Speaking of "creative names," "Dear Abby" yesterday featured a letter from a frustrated friend of a soon-to-be-mother who liked the sounds of the words "chlamydia," "bidet," and "chalet," and thought they'd be nice names for her daughter. The friend wanted to steer her away from them, but the mother's family was supportive.
Quite a few good clue - answer pairs but quite a whole lot of drab non-fun fill ruined it for me. I would have loved the trivia for some of them if I wasn't irritated by them.
For me the toughest clue was ENNEAD and that corner was really slowed down by me filling in TENTS rather than YURTS. ü•≤
Hardest Friday I have done in a long time.  Totally stymied on a bunch of clues. Shamefully had to peek at the answer key ü´£
The good life: some grub, a solo career and a heating pad.

I assumed ENNEAD was the name of one of the Brady family, knowing nothing about said family. I'm astounded to realise there is this word that I have never, ever heard of (that's not a brand name or a sports reference) because that happens very rarely now. 

I do know what STENO means, but I keep forgetting. I've learnt about the Tammany tiger. I looked for a Beatles reference for Help and I looked up HURST, and FLIP OUT ON is only faintly familiar. 

Not too bad!

Thank goodness I knew YURTS, since TNIA was an unknown whose first letter I never would have guessed correctly.

Enjoyed this one a lot. LATVIAN yesterday helped me get RIGA today. ULTRASUEDE was also an unknown, but it was easy enough to work out from the crosses.

Solved this one unaided in about 25 minutes, which is fast for me on a Friday. LUCRE is an interesting word, and it was nice to see that entry in particular.

Phew! That was crunchy. On first pass, only ELOTE, STENO, OVA, and OVALTINE were gimmes for me. Then it slowly cracked open. I finally had to look up the actress because I didn't suspect TNIA was correct.
I really enjoy your puzzles. But I can‚Äôt support this ‚Äúnews org‚Äù any more. Won‚Äôt be renewing at the end of the month. Good luck surviving this wave of cancellations.
Don't ask me how the holy heck I got this one. TNIA crossing with ENNEAD? Luck of the highest order.

I camped out (no YURTS) for what felt like a long, long time in the NE corner, stymied by crosses I couldn‚Äôt guess and deflated in that specifically crosswordian way when one‚Äôs cherished answer isn‚Äôt correct: ‚ÄúSpare things?‚Äùwas PINS and not ‚Äúlend,‚Äù as I really wanted it to be. But as a former bantam-league bowler, I acknowledge it as a perfectly wonderful clue-answer duo. 

There were several lines in here that truly delighted me, and I thank the constructor for her work. Brava! 

One of my can‚Äôt-live-without possessions is my Thermophore HEATING PAD, so please receive the thanks from both me and my Thermophore, who solved it together today :)

Sing in me, Muse, of Carol, lovely, mother of three,
Each, like their mother, gold-tressed; Cindy, the youngest, in curls.
Sing, Goddess, of Brady, the man, sire of three noble sons:
A tetrad they were, stouthearted, loyal, but alone.
Till by Nemesis thrust, this man and this woman, to each other's embraces,
Knew, more than supposed, the two should forge out a household,
(By Hera and Hestia bless'd, daughters of lovely-haired Rhea.)
Lo! Alice appears in their midst, woman of infinite talents:

And thus we became the House Polybradides!

(I leave it to @SL to translate this into flowing Homeric hexameters.)

Great puzzle Kelly Morenus!

This is how I felt after completing today's puzzle: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aCXL4sG021Y&list=RDaCXL4sG021Y&start_radio=1 (Joan Lippincott and friends put a little pedal to the metal) Thank you for a wonderful puzzle, Ms. Morenus!
Crossing TNIA with ENNEAD was brutal.  Fair but tough puzzle.

We all know that clues don't have to be definitions or neat equivalents, but ‚Äújouissance‚Äù still seems a poor match for 51D. My maternal grandmother, born in 1925, spoke French, and it was part of her persona. She was a somewhat tragic character, forever scarred by a tough childhood in the 1930s, after her father, the scion of impoverished gentry, abandoned her and her mother, and then got himself killed in 1939. She spent some time in German during WW2 prison and saw some horrible stuff there. All of that desensitized her. My mother never experienced any affection form her, and neither did I. She was cold and aloof, and even though she mostly lacked intelligence, she thought herself better than everybody else (especially my country bumpkin father, despite his rather illustrious academic and public service career). Speaking French was one of the elements of her fake refinement. Actually, one of the reasons I never learned French was to spite her.

The more I write about these things, the more I'm tempted to publish an essay or a book, maybe, on my Polish experience, as told by a dozen ghosts - my grandmother's, mother's, best childhood friend's, Jorge the Lab's, etc. It might be interesting.
